statement:
Let $R$ be a ring, $A$ and $B$ are projectively equivalent $R$-modules
with two projective resolutions:

$P:\xymatrix{\ldots \ar[r]^{\alpha_2}&P_1\ar[r]^{\alpha_1}&P_0\ar[r]^{\alpha_0}&A\ar[r]&0}$

$Q:\xymatrix{\ldots \ar[r]^{\beta_2}&Q_1\ar[r]^{\beta_1}&Q_0\ar[r]^{\beta_0}&B\ar[r]&0}$

Define
$[P,Q]_n:=P_n\oplus Q_{n-1}\oplus P_{n-2}\oplus Q_{n-3}\oplus\cdots$.
Then
$${\operatorname{Ker}}(\alpha_n)\oplus[Q,P]_n\cong{\operatorname{Ker}}(\beta_n)\oplus[P,Q]_n,$$
for all $n\geq0$. In other words, ${\operatorname{Ker}}(\alpha_n)$ is
projective equivalent to ${\operatorname{Ker}}(\beta_n)$.

We proceed by induction on $n$. If $n=0$, then $[P,Q]_0=P_0$ and
$[Q,P]_0=Q_0$. We have the following two short exact sequences:

$\xymatrix{0\ar[r]&{{\operatorname{Ker}}(P_0\rightarrow A)}\ar[r]&P_0\ar[r]&A\ar[r]&0}$

$\xymatrix{0\ar[r]&{{\operatorname{Ker}}(Q_0\rightarrow B)}\ar[r]&Q_0\ar[r]&B\ar[r]&0}$

Therefore, by Schanuel’s Lemma, $$\begin{aligned}
{\operatorname{Ker}}(\alpha_0)\oplus[Q,P]_0&=&{\operatorname{Ker}}(\alpha_0)\oplus Q_0 \\
&=&{\operatorname{Ker}}(P_0\rightarrow A)\oplus Q_0 \\
&\cong& {\operatorname{Ker}}(Q_0\rightarrow B)\oplus P_0 \\
&=&{\operatorname{Ker}}(\beta_0)\oplus P_0 \\
&=&{\operatorname{Ker}}(\beta_0)\oplus[P,Q]_0,\end{aligned}$$ since $A$
and $B$ are projectively equivalent.

Next, assume the induction step is true for $n=k$. To begin, we first
notice two short exact sequences:
$$\xymatrix{0\ar[r]&{{\operatorname{Ker}}(\alpha_{k+1})}\ar[r]&P_{k+1}\ar[r]&{{\operatorname{Im}}(\alpha_{k+1})}\ar[r]&0}$$
$$\xymatrix{0\ar[r]&{{\operatorname{Ker}}(\beta_{k+1})}\ar[r]&Q_{k+1}\ar[r]&{{\operatorname{Im}}(\beta_{k+1})}\ar[r]&0}$$
Since $P$ and $Q$ are exact,
${\operatorname{Im}}(\alpha_{k+1})={\operatorname{Ker}}(\alpha_k)$ and
${\operatorname{Im}}(\beta_{k+1})={\operatorname{Ker}}(\beta_k)$ and the
two short exact sequences (4) and (5) can be rewritten as:
$$\xymatrix{0\ar[r]&{{\operatorname{Ker}}(\alpha_{k+1})}\ar[r]&P_{k+1}\ar[r]&{{\operatorname{Ker}}(\alpha_k)}\ar[r]&0}$$
$$\xymatrix{0\ar[r]&{{\operatorname{Ker}}(\beta_{k+1})}\ar[r]&Q_{k+1}\ar[r]&{{\operatorname{Ker}}(\beta_k)}\ar[r]&0}$$
Taking direct sums of the above modules with appropriate $[,]_k$’s, we
now have two further short exact sequences:

$\xymatrix{0\ar[r]&{{\operatorname{Ker}}(\alpha_{k+1})\oplus[0,0]_k}\ar[r]&
{P_{k+1}\oplus[Q,P]_k}\ar[r]&
{{\operatorname{Ker}}(\alpha_k)\oplus[Q,P]_k}\ar[r]&0}$

$\xymatrix{0\ar[r]&{{\operatorname{Ker}}(\beta_{k+1})\oplus[0,0]_k}\ar[r]&
{Q_{k+1}\oplus[P,Q]_k}\ar[r]&
{{\operatorname{Ker}}(\beta_k)\oplus[P,Q]_k}\ar[r]&0}$

where the $0$ in $[0,0]_k$ denotes the zero resolution. First,
$${\operatorname{Ker}}(\alpha_{k+1})\oplus[0,0]_k\cong{\operatorname{Ker}}(\alpha_{k+1})\mbox{ and }
{\operatorname{Ker}}(\beta_{k+1})\oplus[0,0]_k\cong{\operatorname{Ker}}(\beta_{k+1}).$$
Second,
$$P_{k+1}\oplus[Q,P]_k=[P,Q]_{k+1}\mbox{ and }Q_{k+1}\oplus[P,Q]_k=[Q,P]_{k+1}$$
are both projective. Finally,
$${\operatorname{Ker}}(\alpha_k)\oplus[Q,P]_k\cong{\operatorname{Ker}}(\beta_k)\oplus[P,Q]_k$$
by the induction hypothesis. Hence, again, by Schanuel’s Lemma,
$$\begin{aligned}
{\operatorname{Ker}}(\alpha_{k+1})\oplus[Q,P]_{k+1}&\cong&{\operatorname{Ker}}(\alpha_{k+1})\oplus[0,0]_k\oplus[Q,P]_{k+1}\\
&=&{\operatorname{Ker}}(\alpha_{k+1})\oplus[0,0]_k\oplus Q_{k+1}\oplus[P,Q]_k\\
&\cong&{\operatorname{Ker}}(\beta_{k+1})\oplus[0,0]_k\oplus P_{k+1}\oplus[Q,P]_k\\
&=&{\operatorname{Ker}}(\beta_{k+1})\oplus[0,0]_k\oplus[P,Q]_{k+1}\\
&\cong&{\operatorname{Ker}}(\beta_{k+1})\oplus[P,Q]_{k+1}\end{aligned}$$
